title: How will going to a wealthy Oxford or Cambridge college actually benefit me?
text:
The Telegraph’s Oxbridge College league table ranks each Oxford and Cambridge college by its financial assets, including endowment and net assets. But why would this matter? Tom Ough explains the financial impact of attending St John’s College, Oxford, the second-wealthiest on our list.

St John’s is legendary among Oxford students for its wealth and largesse. I studied there from 2011 to 2014, and everyone seemed to have a favourite story. One was that St John’s had tried, when building a beautiful quad that opened in 2010, to put a swimming pool underneath it.

The university’s other colleges, according to the legend, vetoed the plan, fearing that St John’s would attract an even larger chunk of applicants than it already did. To new undergraduates, suddenly finding their lips around St John’s enormous, gushing teats, this myth was as much a source of anger – how dare they take away our pool! – as amusement.

Another story had it that St John’s wanted to abolish tuition fees, but was once again foiled by the penny-pinching cartel of Oxford’s other colleges. This story was also probably untrue, but St John’s endowment, at £632 million, is Oxford’s largest and, if it were a GDP, would be bigger than that of Tonga.

Although endowments are not a Scrooge McDuck pile of gold coins, their presence made life a whole lot easier. We ate subsidised food, we drank subsidised booze, we lived in on‑site accommodation that was among the cheapest in Oxford. We had something like £250 a year to spend on books, we had travel grants and scholarships and, if we fell on hard times, we could apply for emergency funding.
description: The Telegraph’s Oxbridge College league table ranks each Oxford and Cambridge college by its financial assets, including endowment and net assets.
